records.rec_Title: Labyrinthus [ Hawkesworth, Walter - comedy : University ]

details.value:
The 1636 printed edition claims that the play was staged before King James, but Wiggins points out that this is unlikely, though it was intended to be revived for the king's aborted 1624 visit (5:32). This claim is why the catalogue entry for the Bodleian copy mis-dates the play to "about A.D. 1625" and states (apparently without evidence) that it was acted before James in March 1623.

The play was performed in 1603, probably in March at the Bachelor's Commencement, the day after Hawkesworth's "Leander" was staged (Wiggins, 5:32).

This copy is included in a volume titled "Comoediae duae. Leander et Labyrinthus." (both plays by Hawkesworth). The copy of "Leander" is dated at the end January 7, 1599.

c. 1630s the play was re-used as the wrapper for the MS "The Telltale."

details.value:
The 1636 printed edition claims that the play was staged before King James, but Wiggins points out that this is unlikely, though it was intended to be revived for the king's aborted 1624 visit (5:32). This claim is why the catalogue entry for the Cambridge copy claims that it was acted in 1622.

The play was performed in 1603, probably in March at the Bachelor's Commencement, the day after Hawkesworth's "Leander" was staged (Wiggins, 5:32).

The other plays in the volume are "Leander" and Brooke's "Scyros". All three plays were copied into the volume by one hand.

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

Printed by B. Field in 1844 for the Shakespeare Society. Another MS. is at Gonville and Caius College (no. 125).

2. To the Chancellor. 13 Kal. Dec. 1621.
3. To Sam. Harsnett Abp designate of York, 18 Nov. 1628.
4. To Sir Francis Cottington, 1628.
5. To Laud, Bp of London.
6. Goodwin, Fellow of Trinity College, to (Marc. Ant. de Dominus). Abp of Spalatro, in St. Mary's Church.

Antipo [ Verney, Francis - tragedy : University ]

details.value:
1r: title page
1v: blank
2r: character list ("Actors")
2v: blank
3r: dedicatory verse
3v: blank
4r: verse to readers ("Ad Lectorem")
4v: blank
5r: prologue ("Prologus")
5v: blank
6r-9v: act one
10r-14r: act two
14v-25v: act three
26r-33v: act four
34r-40r: act five
40v-41v: song
41v: finis and date
43r-47v: appendix describing revisions ("This foresayd tragedye was amended / in the boo<k>e wich I tooke Coppye by. / the correc<t>ing whereof is asfoll<ows>.")

The play was likely written and prepared for a performance at Trinity College, Oxford, while Verney was a student there (on the performance-oriented nature of the revisions, see Pangallo; REED suggests that the play was not performed).

In addition to the other paratexts, the manuscript includes a verse letter to readers ("Ad Lectorum") (f. 4r). Wiggins suggests that the dedication ("Illustrisimo principi: magnae brittaniae") (f. 3r) may have been meant for Prince Henry rather than King James.

In June 1622, while in Alicante, Spain, London merchant Nicholas Leate transcribed the play from a lost exemplar that was probably an authorial manuscript bearing revisions for performance. Leate had been involved with the Levant Company and its pirate-hunting activities at the time that Verney was a pirate in the Mediterranean (1608-1615).

Rather than copy the revised version of the play as it appeared in his exemplar, Leate transcribed the original version (the version that had been superseded by the revisions). He recorded the revisions, however, in an appendix (ff. 42r-46v), noting the specific folio and speech number (which he added in the margins on the pages to which the appendix refers) of the location of the revisions (on this, see Pangallo).

The title page states that the volume includes also "othere poeticall verses" (f. 1r), but no such verses appear in the volume. A later hand, in a lighter ink, wrote a cipher of numbers, letters, and Greek letters on the title page. On the final page of the play proper, Leatt signed the page (f. 41v) and dated it "Allicante / Junij: 10mo: / 1622"; the "1622" was altered by a later hand to 1642. On the title page, the lines "written by mee Nico. Leatt Jun. / in Allicant In June: 1622 :/:" were struck through with thick lines in black ink.

The Bodleian's summary catalogue entry mis-identifies the scribe as "N. Leath" and states incorrectly that the revisions described in the appendix were "variations" from "another copy" of the play.

The role of Francis, the Porter, was played by the college porter, Francis Clarke. Chambers assigns the play's authorship to Clarke.

The foliation for MS Rawlinson poet. 212 is reversed. The miscellany was evidently made by an Oxford student in the early 17th century and it includes letters, poems, epigrams, and prose, including four speeches written for Clarke in other contexts.

Wiggins points out that the prologue refers to the actors as "the King's own lovely subjects", which might indicate that it was copied after King James had become king of England (March 24) and the reference to the monarch silently updated from "Queen's own lovely subjects" (5:1).

Rules are drawn across the page to indicate scene breaks.

Greg suggests that the hand of the main scribe (Hand 1) is identical to the main scribe of the Worcester College, Oxford University, manuscript of Shirley's "The Court Secret" (Worcester College, Plays 9. 21). Peter Beal confirms this identification (http://www.celm-ms.org.uk/repositories/worcester-college-oxford.html#worcester-college-oxford_id723560). 

An additional leaf was inserted into the manuscript (f. 78+); because it is larger than the rest of the leafs, it was folded to fit into the volume.

The manuscript was trimmed at some point, resulting in the loss of some parts of letters in the outer margins.

In October 1661, Samuel Pepys saw it performed and described it as "the first time it hath been acted this twenty-five years" (Bentley, 3:146); this would suggest that it was last performed in 1636. However, the play was included in an August 1641 list of King's Men plays that the Lord Chamberlain prohibited stationers to publish without permission from the troupe, which might suggest that it was still part of their repertory (Bentley, 3:145). 

A. H. Bullen edited the play from the Harley MS 7650 manuscript and was unaware of the 1649 printed edition. He assigned the play entirely to Shirley and titled it "Captain Underwit".

The manuscript (Harley MS 7650) is not included in the British Library's online Archives & Manuscripts Catalogue, nor does it appear in the 4-volume printed catalogue published in 1808 (which only runs through Harley MS 7639). An undated handwritten annotation has been added to the printed catalogue in the British Library Manuscripts Reading Room: "7650 - Formerly Add 5001 - 'A Play - No Name'".

MS Lansdowne contains four plays: 'The Queen of Corsica,' 'The Second Maiden's Tragedy,' 'The Bugbears,' and a fragment of 'The Benefice' by Robert Wild.

Paper is thin, browned, and damp-stained in places, with holes from deterioration. The leaves are marked with a crozier mark which has the letters ILESACE at the bottom. A fine silk gauze has been added to all but fols. 3, 9, 27, and 28, to reinforce the pages, but it tends to obscure the text beneath. Ink has bled on many of the pages, making much of the text extremely difficult to read.

Play is written in the same hand (Italian, with a mix of secretary forms) and with the same ink throughout. Some additions appear in fresher ink, likely after the play was fully transcribed. There is debate whether it is an autograph transcription and whether the alterations were added in the same or a separate hand. Greg maintained it was written out by a professional scribe, with no evidence of being autograph. Clifford Leech and Malone claim that it is, in fact, autograph.

Each Scene lists characters involved and each Act ends with an 'Explicit.' There is space for a Prologue on the blank pages preceding the body of the play (ff 2v-3r) and the heading of 'Epilogue' at the end of the play (f. 28v) but neither was ever written into the manuscript.

details.value:
MS is a collection of surviving manuscript plays gathered by the Somerset Herald John Warburton. Warburton's cook allegedly used much of the rest of the collection of manuscript plays as "pye bottoms" for baking.

At the sale of Warburton's books this collection was bought by Philip Carteret Webb. After Webb's death in 1771, his widow sold the collection to William Petty, Earl of Shelbourne, First Marquis of Lansdowne.

details.value:

Because the manuscript was copied by the scribe who copied "The Parliament of Love", it was presumably also owned by the Lady Elizabeth's Men at The Cockpit in 1623. As in "The Parliament of Love", most stage directions are between horizontal rules, including the warning directions to actors. The warning directions are in the left margin and typically occur approximately twenty lines before the entrance.

Greg wonders whether the deletion of a reference to "the raigne of this kinge heere" (f. 18r) might indicate censorship by the Master of the Revels (279). Nothing else in the manuscript indicates censorship, however, and there is no license.

It is possible that a blank first leaf was once part of the manuscript. 

Damp stains and decay appear on the bottom of all the leaves throughout, obscuring text in some places (these damp stains align with the same stains appearing on the manuscript of "The Parliament of Love"). The library catalogue record states that this damage was caused by mice.

The manuscript was bound around 1821 by Joseph Haselwood, who interleaved blank pages between the manuscript leaves and who began a transcript (one page) of the start of the play.

Wiggins modernizes the title to "The Welsh Ambassador" (7:468). Nigel Bawcutt claims that the play is a collaboration between Dekker and John Ford (Vickers, vol. 3).

f. 317r: date

ff. 1 and 342-45 are later additions and on different paper than the rest of the manuscript. f. 349r is blank; the end of the play, epilogue, and Masters license and note are on the verso.

The play was for a time attributed to East India Company officer William Methold (Methwold) but the authorial hand in the manuscript matches that of Walter Mountfort's petition to the East India Company court (PRO C.O. 77/4, art. 113, ff. 228-29).

While there are generally no speech rules in the manuscript, a few sporadic rules have been added in places, probably at a later time (possibly in the ink that Mountfort used for his post-censorship revisions).
Fingerprints on ff. 325v, 332v, and 333v might be either Mountfort's or Herbert's; later fingerprints appear on 342v and 343r.

There is no internal evidence of performance, but Pangallo (2007) argues that the manuscript was held by the second Prince Charles's Men, who in the summer of 1633 were performing either at the Red Bull or Salisbury Court. While a performance was evidently intended, there is no evidence that it was carried out.

On the paste-down on the front inside cover are two notes. One (presumably by Thomas Drury) reads 'This differs very much from the other ms. copy which I have. The other copy does not contain the songs between the Acts.' The second reads 'This MS prepared in the form of a prompt book. J. Q. Adams.' Lower portion of the initial flyleaf is torn off, but the top of the recto contains the inscription 'The Lady Persalls Booke | borrowed 9r ye 1st 1653.'

Manuscript was transcribed by a single scribe in neat, legible hand using Caroline secretary script with elements of italic. Writing become larger and less tidy as the play progresses. Ink is black, fading to grey. Scribe was careful and accurate in transcribing, with 71 clear errors, though whether those errors were introduced by scribe or were in the original text in unclear. Corrections were frequently made with dampening and scraping the page, the resulting gap filled with flourishes and dashes. No discernable trace of the mistakes are left.

Corrections were twice made, one is possibly a new hand, the other in a definite new hand. Both used italic and paler ink.

The presence of ruled lines and their impressions on subsequent pages has led some to scholars to deem this a prompt book. According to Bentley, 'This manuscript has been creased, and two of the creases used for margins, but the creasing is not according to the system found in several professional prompt manuscripts.' It is most likely not a prompt book, as the blind rules are purely for the scribe. It is a manuscript prepared for reading.

records.rec_Title: The Parliament of Love [ Massinger, Philip - comedy : Adult Professional ]

details.value:
ff. 1r-2v: act 1
ff. 3r-6r: act 2
ff. 6r-10r: act 3
ff.10r-14v: act 4
ff. 14v-19r: act 5
f. 19v: title

A substantial portion at the end of f. 8v is left blank; it was covered in cross-hatching in what appears to have been an attempt by the scribe to indicate that none of the text of the play was omitted.

The nature of the revisions made by the second hand include corrections, deletions, and rewording. This hand also added the play's title on the verso of the final leaf.

One notable feature of the stage directions is that many of the entrance directions in the right margin--particularly those that start new scenes--appear between two horizontal rules or within a box.

The manuscript suffers from extensive damage and appears to be missing 2 leaves at the beginning (comprising probably 2 or 3 scenes). The first leaf is mostly decayed and part of the text is illegible. The bottom of the final leaf (f. 19) was cut off before 1803, resulting in the loss of what was apparently Sir Henry Herbert's license (though there is no other evidence of playhouse use or the Master of the Revels' censorship in the manuscript). Damp stains appear on the bottom of every page--particularly the earlier portion of the play--and align with the damp stains on the manuscript of "The Welsh Embassador".

The text of the missing license was recorded by G. Chalmers in his 1799 "Supplemental Apology" (p. 219):

"[1624] 3 November. For the Cockpit Company; A new Play, called, The Parliament of Love: Written by Massinger."

"The Parliament of Love" was entered in the Stationers' Register by Humphrey Moseley on June 29, 1660 as part of an entry of eleven plays attributed to William Rowley, but it was evidently never printed (Lea claims that the extant manuscript is the one that Moseley had, but there is no evidence of this [vi]). The play is also named (as by William Rowley) among the list of manuscripts belonging to John Warburton and supposedly destroyed by his servant.

The manuscript of the play is bound into a single volume with the 1813 edition, F. G Waldron's 1805 manuscript contributions of speculations on the missing material which he gave to Gifford, and a letter from Edmond Malone (who thought the main hand in the manuscript was Massinger's own) to Gifford upon lending him the manuscript. During binding in the 19th century, blank leaves were interleaved between the manuscript pages.

records.rec_Title: Henry IV [ Shakespeare, William - history : ]

details.value: The History of King Henry IV

MS is an early adaptation by Sir Edward Dering combining "1 Henry IV" and "2 Henry IV." The text of Part I was derived from the Fifth Quarto of "1 Henry IV," printed in 1613 by William White for Matthew Law. The second half is derived from the 1600 Quarto of "2 Henry IV."

Initially transcribed by Dering, the MS was later finished by the scribe 'mr Carington." Six (fos. 38-43) of the fifty six leaves are cancels. On Thurs. 27 Feb. 1622/3, Dering paid Carington 4s for the job. This version of the play was likely created for a private theatrical performance, as the original actors included members of Dering's family.

records.rec_Title: Hispanus [ Anonymous - comedy : University ]

details.value:
MS contains two distinct versions of the play: A. as originally acted in 1597 and B. the revised version indicated by amendments and additions at the end of the MS. MS was transcribed into a collection, also containing "Silvanus" (Wiggins 1054) and "Machiavellus" (Wiggins 1090)

The MS was edited in another hand c. 1600-20; the new scribe added revisions on 7 leaves at the end of the text.

Original author of the play is possibly Roger Morrell.

records.rec_Title: The Diseased Knight [ Bacon, Francis - tournament entertainment : Occasional ]

details.value:
MS is fire damaged and thus missing portions of the text. Burgoyne assumes than an incomplete five-line passage of the prose on the verso (pg. 54) is also a part of the speech, but the destruction of the bottom of the leaf makes it impossible to demonstrate textual continuity. The verso passage is also addressed to the Queen, but is spoken in the first person rather than the third, which would be unusual for a tiltyard speech.

MS included in a MS collection of literary and political writings probably prepared for Henry Nevill.

Entertainment featuring an Indian Prince [ Devereux, Robert - entertainment : Occasional ]
Pastoral Entertainment [ Anonymous - entertainment : Occasional ]

details.value: MS is the text of a letter, supposedly from Amyntas, offering to come and 'make such sport this night in square play.' Nichols calls it "A Prologue to Square Play," which he takes to be a type of sport to be shown by the boys, and the catalogue of the Herrick papers calls it "Prologue to The Square Play," generating a ghost title. It is not a formal prologue, and the phrase "square play" refers to an honest game of chance.

The papers are a miscellaneous collection of literary items dating mainly from the the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. The text is in a hand from the earlier part of the period and is therefore probably associated with Sir William Herrick (c. 1562-1653) and the Herrick family in Leicestershire.

Once owned, and indexed, by J.G. Nichols.

records.rec_Title: Entertainment at Gray’s Inn [ Bacon, Francis - entertainment : Occasional ]

details.value:
MS contains prince's and first three councillor's speeches only. 

The speeches were most likely from the "orations at Gray's Inn Revels" transcribed c. 1957 in MS collection of literary and political writings, many by Bacon, probably prepared for Henry Nevill. The "orations" and their their author are listed on the first leaf, but the text does not appear in the surviving portion of the MS (Alnwick Castle, MS 525).

The stage directions "Enter Time" and "Exit" at the beginning and end of this text are the only indications that it is a dramatic manuscript, rather than just a poem.

records.rec_Title: The Massacre at Paris [ Marlowe, Christopher - tragedy : Adult Professional ]

details.value:
MS fragment is fuller in dialogue content and superior as a piece of writing, but otherwise differs little from printed version. Contains one scene, including entrances and exits.

Play may have been performed with the abbreviated title of "Massacre," though the printed title is "The Massacre at Paris." Contemporary titles include "The Tragedy of the Guise," "The Massacre of France" and "The Massacre of Paris." Later versions were assigned the title of "The Duke of Guise." Witnesses disagree on whether the title included "of" or "at" before Paris, or that is was "of France."

records.rec_Title: 3 Richardus Tertius [ Legge, Thomas - tragedy : University ]

details.value:
Legge finished writing the play by the end of 1578, when St. John's College paid 3 shillings for paper "to write out the books for the tragedy" (Wiggins, 2:227). This MS may have been used as the copy-text for Cambridge University Library MS Mm. 4.40 (Wiggins, 2:227). Title page names author and refers to performance.

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

records.rec_Title: 3 Richardus Tertius [ Legge, Thomas - tragedy : University ]

details.value:
Legge finished writing the play by the end of 1578, when St. John's College paid 3 shillings for paper "to write out the books for the tragedy" (Wiggins, 2:227). 

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

A colophon at the end of this manuscript gives the name Anthony Cady [Cade] and the date 1583. On the title page, the date "1582" has been erased and the name of "Anthonius Cadus" is given, as well as the note "Descriptor ex autoris autographo, A. Cadi manu", indicating that Cade made his copy from a manuscript that he believed to be authorial. Wiggins suggests Cade's transcription was made "with a view to the text's being printed" (2:228).

A note by J. O. Halliwell on the flyleaf claims that "the original of this play is in MS. in St. John's College Library", but no such copy is extant. Halliwell also identifies the Gonville and Caius College copy and notes that the parchment in which that copy is bound "is part of a Missal" (the catalogue for the Clare College Library erroneously interprets Halliwell's note as referring to the binding of the Clare College copy).

details.value:
Legge finished writing the play by the end of 1578, when St. John's College paid 3 shillings for paper "to write out the books for the tragedy" (Wiggins, 2:227). 

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

The other two plays bound into the volume are "Hymenaeus" and "Paedantius".

records.rec_Title: 1 Richardus Tertius [ Legge, Thomas - tragedy : University ]

details.value:
Legge finished writing the play by the end of 1578, when St. John's College paid 3 shillings for paper "to write out the books for the tragedy" (Wiggins, 2:227). 

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

A colophon at the end of this manuscript gives the name Anthony Cady [Cade] and the date 1583. On the title page, the date "1582" has been erased and the name of "Anthonius Cadus" is given, as well as the note "Descriptor ex autoris autographo, A. Cadi manu", indicating that Cade made his copy from a manuscript that he believed to be authorial. Wiggins suggests Cade's transcription was made "with a view to the text's being printed" (2:228).

A note by J. O. Halliwell on the flyleaf claims that "the original of this play is in MS. in St. John's College Library", but no such copy is extant. Halliwell also identifies the Gonville and Caius College copy and notes that the parchment in which that copy is bound "is part of a Missal" (the catalogue for the Clare College Library erroneously interprets Halliwell's note as referring to the binding of the Clare College copy).

records.rec_Title: 1 Richardus Tertius [ Legge, Thomas - tragedy : University ]

details.value:
Legge finished writing the play by the end of 1578, when St. John's College paid 3 shillings for paper "to write out the books for the tragedy", presumably one of which was this copy and another was Huntington Library MS HM 179, ff. 1-27, which might have served as the copy-text for this one (Wiggins, 2:227). 

The Cambridge University Library catalogue suggests that the corrections in this MS were made by Legge.

The play was performed in March 1579 for the St. John's College, Cambridge, Bachelors' Commencement Feast and on March 17, 1583 at the College for the visit of the earl of Essex.

records.rec_Title: Welsh Interlude [ Aspull, Thomas - interlude : Unknown ]

details.value: Written 1582 by Thomas Aspull on Monday 22 October, though Aspull may have only been the scribe. Only one leaf now survives, most of the play is lost. This piece is the labeled the first interlude (yr...enterluwt gynta), which might imply that a sequel or other follow-up existed.

details.value: Transcribed by Fraunce in MS. The other two plays bound into the volume are "Hymenaeus" and "Paedantius".

details.value:
The manuscript appears in a miscellany belonging to "Lew. F." (Leweston Fitzjames).

The play was written by a fellow at New College, Oxford. Wiggins suggests that the character "Jenken" is meant to be the author (3:200). A marginal note in the manuscript identifies a reference in the play to John Hoskins (1566-1638), who was also a fellow at New College, Oxford.

Original owner (ca. 1609): Leweston Fitzjames (1574-1638).
1884: acquired by the British Museum.

records.rec_Title: Friar Bacon and John of Bordeaux [ Greene, Robert - romance : Adult Professional ]

details.value:
Authorship of the play is undetermined. William Lindsay Renwick, the Malone Society editor, argues for Greene on the basis of the play's relationship to "Friar Bacon and Friar Bungay"; McNeir supports Renwick's argument, though Wiggins considers the relationship between the play and its prequel to be insufficient grounds for the attribution (3:138).

This play might be the "Play of Bacon" for which Henslowe, on 14 December 1602, advanced Thomas Downton five shillings to pay Middleton for a new prologue and epilogue for a court performance. Possibly this court performance was one of the three plays the Lord Admiral's Men performed at Whitehall on 27 December 1602, Richmond on 6 March 1603, and (possibly) 8 March 1603. The other performances listed in this record relate to a play known as "Friar Bacon" in Henslowe's diary; presumably, this is that play.

In the manuscript, three stage directions name John Holland in the role of Ferdinand. Holland was an actor in Strange's Men and possibly Pembroke's Men around 1590-1593.

The speech prefixes are typically one to three lines too high, suggesting that the text of the speeches on each page was copied out and then the prefixes added after.

Renwick argues that the play as it appears in the manuscript is a truncated version of a longer play (vii). The sequence for the manuscript's history that Renwick proposes is that a theatrical company around 1592 desired a shortened version of the complete play; after 1598 (when Chettle apparently became active in the theater) the same or another company wished to revive the play and had Chettle fill in a gap in the copy (Renwick, xiii).

The play was bound into a single volume with "The Wasp", probably around 1870-1872 (Renwick, v). Folio 13 was misbound in between f. 11 and f. 12.

The manuscript is heavily damaged in places and the final leaf is torn, resulting in the loss of most of the text on it.
Friar Bacon and John of Bordeaux

records.rec_Title: The Solitary Knight [ Anonymous - tournament entertainment : Occasional ]

details.value:
Written for performance before Queen Elizabeth, possibly September 20-21, 1592, during a royal visit to Sir Henry Lee's home at Ditchley (the entertainment was written for performance at a great house, not at court in London). Lee possibly played the part of the solitary knight.

This manuscript is a copy of the speech of the woodman who serves the solitary knight. It is bound into a collection of Lee's speeches, poems, and other materials related to entertainments presented before Queen Elizabeth.

The speech is signed with the initials "J:g:", which might indicate either the author or the scribe who copied out the manuscript (the manuscript is not in Lee's hand). The British Library catalogue record suggests that this might be "John Grove".

Late sixteenth to early seventeenth century: owned by Sir Henry Lee.
Late nineteenth to early twentieth century: owned by Viscount Harold Arthur Lee-Dillon.

The Knight of Pendragon Castle [ Anonymous - tilt : Occasional ]

details.value: Speech of Lord Cumberland delivered to Queen Elizabeth in the Tilt yard at Whitehall when, taking upon him the name of the Knight of Pendragon Castle

The text is Merlin's speech to Queen Elizabeth. The tilt was performed before the queen by George Clifford, 3rd earl of Cumberland and others.

Richard Robinson made the manuscript on June 29, 1661, when it was, he notes, "coppied out of the Originall which Mr Robert Hilton of Murton lent me." On November 3, 1663, Robinson collated his copy against the original text of the tilt, which was, at the time, at Pendragon Castle.

In the heading of his copy, Robinson misdated the entertainment to 1592.

Note: Wiggins gives the CRO's older shelf mark for this item (WD/Hoth Acc. A988 6).

records.rec_Title: John a Kent and John a Cumber [ Munday, Anthony - comedy : Adult Professional ]

details.value: John a Kent and John a Cumber

front wrapper: title
1r-4r: act one
4r-6v: act two
6v-9r: act three
9r-12r: act four
12r-13v: act five

Wiggins suggests that that "[t]here are indications of authorial composition in the MS, though it might also be argued that Munday was only tinkering with the text during the preparation of a later fair copy" (3:53).

In addition to the marginal folding for alignment, the paper was folded in the middle as well.

The manuscript has some damage from damp; folio 13 is torn in such a way that some text is lost and the edges of the paper are torn in places, resulting in some loss of words or parts of words. Sir Edward Maunde Thompson suggested that two or three leaves are missing between f. 12 and 13, but as the Malone Society editor, Muriel St. Clare Byrne, points out, this is unlikely since there appears to be no lacuna in the text (St. Clare Byrne, v). Folio 14 of the manuscript, however, is evidently missing; St. Clare Byrne suggests that it might have had a character list (St. Clare Byrne, vi).

The original binding was made from the vellum of two medieval manuscripts; one of these leafs (the "Compilatio Prima" of Bernard of Pavia) was also used for the binding of the manuscript play "Sir Thomas More" (St. Clare Byrne, vi).

records.rec_Title: Tomumbeius [ Salterne, George - tragedy : Unknown ]

details.value: Tomumbeius, sive Sultanici in Aegypto imperil eversio

The dedication is to Queen Elizabeth, which indicates that the manuscript was made by at least 1603. Roberta Barker, the editor of The Philological Museum edition online, suggest that the composition of the play dates to the 1580s or, more likely, the early 1590s, when the play might have been written for closet reading by Salterne's coterie at the Inns of Court.

The same hand that copied out the play and its paratexts also included in the manuscript a Latin eclogue ("Algaeus") and a different hand has copied out an English paraphrase poem of Psalm 13 (ff. 39r-48v).

Late 15th or early 16th century: owned by the author, George Salterne of Bristol
1697: owned by Nathaniel Johnson
Late 17th or early 18th century: Michael Maittaire
Early 18th century: Richard Rawlinson
1755: bequeathed by Rawlinson to the Bodleian

records.rec_Title: 3 Solymitana Clades [ Legge, Thomas - tragedy : Unacted ]

details.value:
The play was evidently intended for performance at Caius College, Cambridge University, where Legge was vice chancellor, but it was apparently unacted. 

Francis Meres mentions the trilogy in his "Palladis Tamia" (1598) but Legge continued to revise it up until 1607, when it was reputedly stolen (Wiggins, 3:27).

This manuscript has lacunae in 2.2, 3.5, 5.5, and 5.6 and is unfinished (Wiggins, 3:21).

records.rec_Title: Rowland's Godson [ Anonymous - jig : Occasional ]

details.value:
The entire jig was sung to the tune of "Loath to Depart".

It is referenced in Thomas Nashe's "Summer's Last Will and Testament" (printed 1600).

The jig might be related to two titles entered into the Stationers' Register by John Wolfe in 1592: "The First Part of Rowland's Godson Moralized" (April 18) and "The Second Part of Rowland's Godson Moralized" (April 29).

The oblong 24-leaf volume in which it appears is written in one hand and contains ballads and songs. A brief description is provided in Clark, 334 (Clark also provides modernized editions of most of the contents).

The epilogue refers to William of Wykeham, founder of Winchester College; Wiggins suggests that this might indicate performance at the school and notes that the only records of performances there are for Christmas 1565, Christmas 1573, 1582-3, and 1589-90 (3:1 and 4).

The division of the acts and scenes is extremely confused, probably as a result of the work being divided up between six different copyists, each of whom wrote out a few pages.

At one time--possibly in the early eighteenth century--the volume in which the play is bound (Harley 5110) was apparently part of a uniform collection of manuscripts that included also Harley 5108, 5109, and 5111.

1: text copied out by at least six different scribes
2: corrections made to transcript, possibly the author

records.rec_Title: The Marriage Between Wit and Wisdom [ Merbury, Francis - morality : Unknown ]

details.value:
f. 1r: title-page, character list (with division of the parts for six actors), and date
f. 1v: blank
ff. 2r-2v: prologue
ff. 2v-32r: play (on f. 20v there is an act-break designation for act two, but there are no other act breaks in the manuscript)
f. 32r-v: epilogue
f. 32v: author's name

Damage to the top of the first leaf obscures the first part of the title. Conjectured readings include "The contract of A" and "The enterlud of A" (see Lennam, 1 and Wiggins, 2:129).

Unlike most character lists in manuscript plays, the list on the title-page of this manuscript provides for doubling ("The deuision of the partes for six to playe this / interlude").

The layout of the pages (centered speech prefixes and stage directions, doubling character list) might suggest that the play was copied from a now-lost printed version, possibly printed by John Allde (see Lennam, ix-x; Wiggins, 2:131); alternatively, it may have been copied in such a peculiar way simply to emulate the look of a play printed by Allde.

On June 23, 1591, in the Stationers' Register, Thomas Orwin was granted right to "The mariage of wyt and wisdome" by Edward Marsh. This might be a reference to "The Marriage of Wit and Science, which was entered to Thomas Marsh in August 1569 and printed soon after (see Lennam, ix; Wiggins, 2:131). However, a "Marriage of Wit and Wisdom" appears as one of the plays performed by the players in Anthony Munday's "Sir Thomas More" (ca. 1590) and a printed edition is listed in Rogers and Ley's 1656 "exact and perfect catalogue of all Places that are Printed" (Lennam, ix).

Merbury was a student at Christ's College, Cambridge, from 1571 to 1578; Lennam suggests that he wrote the play earlier in his career there (Lennam, xi; see also Wiggins, 2:129).
The Marriage Between Wit and Wisdom

records.rec_Title: Misogonus [ Anonymous - comedy : Unknown ]

details.value: A mery and pleasant comedy called Misogonus

1r: title-page and character list (showing doubling for ten actors)
1v: prologue
2r-7r: act one
7r-15v: act two
15v-20v: act three
21r-24v: act four

Damage to the manuscript ("a very tatty MS" according to Wiggins [2:177]) results in the loss of the end of 1.4, start of 1.5, and the end of the play; a leaf is missing between f. 6 and f. 7, and after f. 24, and a third of f. 4 is torn away. Barber assumes that the play included an epilogue, but there is nothing in the extant manuscript that specifically requires this (Barber, 282).

The character list provides a plan for doubling for ten actors.

Possibly intended for performance at Trinity College, Cambridge and later staged at the Kettering Grammar School. The author might have been Laurence Johnson (the scribal corrector who signed and dated the title page, "Kettering die 20 Novembers Anno 1577) or Anthony Rudd (whose name appears on f. 1r). Other names in the manuscript include "Thomas Rychardes" (possibly the scribe), "Thomas Ward" on f. 1v (with the added note, "1577, Barfold"), "W. Wyllm." on f. 11v (apparently in the role of Sir John), and "John York. Iesu." on f. 17r (apparently in the role of Alison).

Barber proposes that Rudd wrote the play between 1564 and 1577 for performance at Cambridge; when Laurence Johnson, master of the Kettering grammar school, needed a play, he remember Rudd's play from their college days and Richards made a copy of it for him. Johnson then made corrections. Then Richards added Rudd's name on the title-page to give him credit as author. (Barber, 22)

records.rec_Title: Love Feigned and Love Unfeigned [ Anonymous - morality : Unknown ]

details.value:
a1r-v, ii8r-v: text of the play
ii8v: song

This fragment (243 lines) appears copied onto the first and final leafs of a printed book (Johannes Herolt, "Sermones Discipuli", Strasbourg, 1492).

On the basis of some of the creative changes made by the scribe in correcting the copy, the Malone Society editor, Arundell Esdaile, suggests that the copyist was also the author (MSC 1.1, 17). Wiggins, however, points out that errors that were left to stand, as well as some of the copying errors, suggest otherwise, as does the apparent difference between when the play was written (see below) and when it was copied (both Esdaile and Wiggins, as well as G. F. Warner, date the hand to the first part of the seventeenth century) (Wiggins, 2:61-62).

On the basis of the play's content, Wiggins suggests a composition date of 1560s-1570s, and on the basis of the centered speech prefixes and double-column setting for the song, he suggests that it was copied from a (no longer extant) printed play (Wiggins, 2:61-63).

records.rec_Title: July and Julian [ Anonymous - comedy : School ]

details.value: A new comodi of Ivli and Ivlian

f. 94r: title-page
ff. 94v-95v: prologue
ff. 95v-102v: act one
ff. 102v-107r: act two
ff. 107r-114v: act three
ff. 115r-120v: act four
ff. 120v-134r: act five
ff. 134v-135v: epilogue

The prologue indicates that the play was staged by a company of boys, probably at a grammar school; it also suggests that it had been previously staged by a men's company. 

The miscellany in which the play appears is Gile Lodge's lute-book, which contains 39 pieces of lute music, recipes, and remedies, among other notes. The compiler of the miscellany seems to have had the initials "E. B." (see f. 136r).

Five other hands (beyond the two noted here) appear in the volume, mostly making minor markings and corrections. One of these belonged to "Richard Bunney"; possibly, then, "E.B." was his brother, the theologian and divine Edmund Bunny (1540-1618) (Dawson, xii).

While the play contains no traditional stage directions, it does include (in secretary hand, centered on the page) the list of names of the characters in the scene.

records.rec_Title: The Bugbears [ Jeffere, John - comedy : Unknown ]

details.value:
ff. 57r-60v: act one
ff. 60v-64r: act two
ff. 64r-66v: act three
ff. 67r-70r: act four
ff. 70r-75r: act five
f. 75r: song (as epilogue)
f. 76r-v: music (for "The Fourth Song" and for "The Last Song")

Damage to f. 61 has resulted in the loss of some text (parts of 2.2 and 2.3). Clark also proposes that the manuscript once had a title-page with a character list on the verso and an additional leaf of music at (f. 77) at the end (Clark, 1).

Clark argues that the copy is "at least once removed from the author's foul papers" (Clark, 4). He observes also that the division of labor for copying was done in such a way as to allow the five scribes to work almost simultaneously on their separate sections before the leafs were bound together in folio (Clark, 3-4).

The title on the manuscript was added (on the top of f. 57r) in a later (italic) hand.

The heading for the fourth song (f. 76r) reads, "Giles peperel for Iphigenia" (in three different hands); Clark proposes that Giles Pepperill played the part of Iphigenia (Clark, 23).

The play was possibly written by Sir John Jefferay (Jeffere) of Chiddingly while he was a student at Gray's Inn, possibly for an Inns of Court performance (see Clark, 27-30).

   1a: C copies out 64r to top half of 66r

6: I incompletely adds marginal crosses to mark shared lines and expands or adds speech prefixes, possibly, Clark suggests, attempting to prepare the manuscript for either performance (perhaps concurrent with the work of H) or printing (Clark, 7)
7: J adds two brief marginal comments on 72v and 75r

records.rec_Title: Sapientia Salomonis [ Anonymous - biblical : School ]

details.value:
ff. 1-2: blank
f. 3r: title-page
ff. 3v-4r: blank
f. 4v: character list
ff. 5r-v: prologue
f. 6r: argument
f. 6v: blank
ff. 7r-33v: play
ff. 34r-v: epilogue

This is a fine presentation copy prepared for Queen Elizabeth (the cover displays the royal arms and "E.R." appears in gold on the spine; the initials "E.R." appear in black on a blue field on the illuminated title-page, after the character list, and after the prologue), who attended the January 17, 1566 performance at Westminster School. Expenses associated with the performance, including the making of the manuscripts, are given in Westminster Abbey Muniment 54000 (reproduced in Payne). The school paid 12d "for paper otherwise bestowed on wryting owe the childrenes partes", but these are no longer extant. In addition to the Queen's copy, four other copies were made, also bound in vellum with silk ribbon strings, but these are no longer extant. Two of these were written out -- "thone in text, thither in romaine hande" -- by "Mr Allen his sonne", who was paid 6s, 8d. The school spent: 17d "for three quiar of fyne pap[er] for three copies of the saide Enterlude"; 8d "for twoo other quire of meane pap[er] for twoo other copies of the sayde entrelude"; 2s for "for the bynding of one copie in vellume with the Queenes ma[ies]tie hir armes & silk ribben stringes"; 2s, 8d "for the bynding of fowre other copies in vellum with stringes of sylke"; 8d "for vermilon to make redd nike for intremingling the L[ett]res of the sayde copies therewith"; and 4d "for blacke inke to wright the same".

The red ink was used for decorations and for the speech prefixes. An entirely different ink was used on f. 5r for the added non sequitur line, "Nulla dies sine linea".

Payne identifies a French watermark (not in Gravell): "EDMONDE N18E" (Payne, 45-46).

One of the other presentation copies was owned by Rev. Thomas Corser (1793-1876) and then (after 1876) one "Molini"; another (or possibly the same) was owned by E. N. Adler in 1941.

Trinity College, Cambridge, also staged a "Sapientia Salomonis" in 1559-60, but Wiggins argues that this manuscript represents a completely independent adaptation of Sixt Birck's 1547 version (1:433). Lancashire claims the Westminster boys performed the play again at Putney in 1567 (1310); however, Wiggins points out that the record upon which this claim is based (ES, 2:73) does not give the specific title of the play and so it might not have been "Sapientia Salomonis" (Wiggsin, 1:435).

Processus Satanae [ Anonymous - morality : Unknown ]

details.value: These fragments contain speeches for the character of God, along with some stage directions and cues spoken by the characters Angel, Christ, Verity, Peace, and Satan. The third strip concludes with the name "Jiggons", which may be the scribe's name or possibly that of the actor. Another hand has added the label "old verses | Fro[m] limebrook" (frag. 1v). The play was likely a local morality production staged in the village of Limebrook, Herefordshire. The scribe left blanks for words that he evidently could not read in his exemplar; all but one of these he later filled out (in the same ink).

Performing Economic Thought: English Drama and Mercantile Writing, 1600-1642 Ryner, Bradley 2014

details.value: Performing Economic Thought: English Drama and Mercantile Writing, 1600-1642

value.title: Ryner, Bradley

details.value: This book argues for a generative relationship between economic thought and dramatic form in early modern English drama by examining representations of economic exchange in plays and mercantile treatises written in the early decades the seventeenth century when economic thinkers associated with “mercantilism” were re-examined how they conceptualised and depicted commerce as a system. Treatises by Thomas Milles, Gerard Malynes, Edward Misselden, and Thomas Mun are considered alongside plays by William Shakespeare, Thomas Middleton, Walter Mountfort, Thomas Heywood, Ben Jonson, Philip Massinger, and Richard Brome. Adapting approaches pioneered by scholars of Science Studies and the Rhetoric of Economics, Bradley Ryner compares the formal features of mercantile treatises and plays. He argues that Renaissance playwrights crafted absorbingly self-reflexive models of economic exchange by making productive use of the imperfection of their metaphors, the representational instability of their props and characters, the necessarily limited vantage points of their audiences, and the interpretive energies and generic expectations of these audiences. He shows how these techniques facilitated thinking through questions that were pertinent to seventeenth-century audiences, such as how to conceptualise royal finanace, currency exchange, global trade, and poverty as part of a systemic totality -- an ‘economy’ in the modern sense.

records.rec_Title: Ryner, Bradley
Separation Scenes: Domestic Drama in Early Modern England Christensen, Ann 2017

details.value: Separation Scenes: Domestic Drama in Early Modern England

value.title: Christensen, Ann

details.value:
This analysis of five exemplary domestic plays—the anonymous Arden of Faversham and A Warning for Fair Women (1590s), Thomas Heywood’s A Woman Killed with Kindness (1607), Thomas Middleton’s Women Beware Women (ca. 1613), and Walter Mountfort’s The Launching of the Mary, or The Seaman’s Honest Wife (1632)—offers a new approach to the emerging ideology of the private and public, or what Ann C. Christensen terms “the tragedy of the separate spheres.” Feminist scholarship has identified the fruitful gaps between theories and practices of household government in early modern Europe, while work on the global Renaissance attends to commercial expansion, cross-cultural encounters, and colonial settlements. Separation Scenes brings these critical concerns together to expose the intimate and disruptive relationships between the domestic culture and business culture of early modern England.
 
Separation Scenes argues that domestic plays make the absence of husbands for business the subject of tragedy by focusing not on where men traveled but on whom and what they left behind. Elements that critics have rightly associated with domestic tragedy—adultery, sensational murders, and the lavishly articulated operations of domestic life—define this world, which, Christensen argues, was equally shaped by the absence of husbands. Her interpretations of these domestic plays invite us to historicize and further complicate the seemingly universal binary between a feminine “private sphere” and a masculine “public sphere.”
 
Separation Scenes demonstrates how domestic drama played an active, dynamic, and critical role in deliberating the costs of commercial travel as it disrupted domestic conduct and prompted realignments within the home.
